28 : SUSQUEHANNA ‘R1VvER BRIDGE

With these loadings the stresses were calculated in all the members as-
suming constant moment of inertia and the use of the equation of three
moments. This method, while approximate, is sufficiently accurate for
purposes of this report and in estimating weights. Areas of the different
members required to resist the calculated stresses were computed. Material
is, all carbon steel.

A f
”

The chord sections are of general type:— ,
247







20"

The diagonals are of general type:— r—- =l

Varies 18-24"







L _ vy
T r
The hangers are of general type:— l 20”
' e X
12” & 15
The posts are of general type:— ;' '5'—_2_&
v



The weight of all these members was then computed including weight of
lacing plates, ete., and to this weight 30 per cent was added for details.
Bracing.—The bracing is designed to resist the wind stresses designated in
specifications and to provide rigidity. The top chord lateral system con-
sists of two angle tension members below stringers and connected to stringers
for support. _JL__ The bottom chord laterals are four angles with lacing,

' . ‘ p
thus: _‘: l 10" placed as a K system in each panel carrying both tension and
|

compression. The bottom struts are wide flange beams 10 inch WF 49 lbs.
per foot. Sway frames are placed at panel points and made up of two angles

with lacing, thus: |5« |. The general arrangement of the bracing is in-
dicated in Figure 6. The weight of the members of bracing system was
computed includinglacing, and to thisweight 35 per cent was added for details.
Three Span Continuous Truss Spans

The trusses are 55 feet center to center, and the panel lengths were varied
as indicated in Figure 7 to keep proper slope of diagonals.
